meanings.definition: To treat someone as a celebrity or idol.
meanings.sent1: At the party, the guests lionised the famous actor, asking for autographs and photos.
meanings.sent2: The singer was lionised by fans wherever she went, with people clamoring to get a glimpse of her.
meanings.sent3: The little girl lionised her pet hamster, dressing it up in tiny outfits and showing it off to her friends.
meanings.sent4: The local hero was lionised by the community, his name becoming synonymous with bravery and selflessness.
meanings.sent5: The teacher lionised the student who won the science fair, praising their hard work and dedication.

meanings.definition: To give someone a lot of attention and admiration.
meanings.sent1: The artist was lionised by art critics for his unique style and creativity.
meanings.sent2: The young actress was lionised by the media, with magazines featuring her on their covers.
meanings.sent3: The cat lionised the new scratching post, spending hours sharpening its claws on it.
meanings.sent4: The chef was lionised by food enthusiasts for his innovative dishes and culinary skills.
meanings.sent5: The athlete was lionised by sports fans for his record-breaking performances on the field.

meanings.definition: To make someone famous or well-known.
meanings.sent1: The reality show lionised its contestants, turning them into household names overnight.
meanings.sent2: The viral video lionised the young musician, propelling her to stardom in a matter of days.
meanings.sent3: The toddler lionised his favorite toy, carrying it everywhere and showing it to everyone he met.
meanings.sent4: The company's marketing campaign lionised their new product, attracting a large customer base.
meanings.sent5: The author was lionised by readers around the world, with her books becoming bestsellers in multiple countries.
